titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VII:45. Finished my Letter to the Secretary of State, but the Journal was consequently neglected— Whenever I lose an hour of the morning, the consequence inevitable is, arrears, either of the Journal, or of the Correspondence—often of both. This day Mr Huxley gave his concluding lesson of writing and arithmetic to my three Sons, and I settled with him. It was also the day for them to return to school; but as the exercises do not begin until next Monday, we have indulged them in remaining at home until Sunday Evening. I walked with George, round through Gunnersbury Acton and Ealing; as we were coming back we met two Stages full of boys, returning to the School— After dinner, I began reading Foster’s fourth and last Essay, on the Causes which have rendered evangelical religion unacceptable to persons of a cultivated taste— The weather is yet cold and clear, and the roads of course dry— Just after Sun rise this Morning, I took Fahrenheits Thermometer into the Garden, and found it fell to 25. It has scarcely been colder as yet, this winter.

2. V:45. Morning again cold; and I was occupied during great part of it, in arranging papers; a labour, which now devolves upon me at the beginning of every Month. Mr Smith sent me out a Card from Coll: Drayton, with a Letter of Introduction of him, from Mr Monroe, dated in July last— Coll: Drayton has been several Months at Paris, from whence he has just arrived. There was also a Letter, brought by him, as I presume, from Mr Warden, at Paris— He sends me a Description of the District of Columbia, a small volume lately published by him; and copies of a circular written by him to his friends in Novr: 1814. containing his statement of the circumstances under which he had been removed from the Consular Office, or suspended in the exercise of its functions, by Mr Crawford; and a Letter from the Prince of Benevent, Talleyrand, to him, certifying that the intercourse of the French Government with him after the arrival of Mr Crawford, was not at his own request, but only selon l’usage; Mr Crawford’s functions having commenced only after he had delivered his credentials— After spending a couple of hours upon my Journal, I walked with George through Hanwell and Ealing— But the cold had abated, and we had rain the latter half of our walk, which nearly drenched us. George was unwell after it. In the Evening, I read a few pages of Foster’s Essay.

3. V:30. The day was employed upon the Journal, and sufficed only to bring it up to the close of the preceding Month— The Postman who delivers and takes the Letters, came to request a certificate of his having been always regular in his duty with regard to my Letters— He has been suspended in his office, as he says, upon a complaint that a single Letter which should have been delivered in the Evening, was not delivered until the next Morning; but he says the delay was not by him. He wanted the Certificate, and those of other persons residing in the neighbourhood whom he serves as Postman, to be restored to his place. I gave him the certificate— We took an early dinner, and went into Town, taking our three Sons with us— We first called at the Office in Craven-Street. Mr Smith was gone out— I left the Packets of desptaches and Letters for America, and took several Letters, which I found there upon the table for me— We went to the Sans Pareil Theatre in the Strand; and saw Love in a Vintage, a sort of Ballet— The Inscription, a Melo-drame in Rhyme, and The Witch and the Owl a Pantomime with a Harlequin, better than that which we saw on Monday, at Covent-Garden— The Theatre is small but handsome— The performances indifferent. The house was very thin. In the intervals between the performances I read my Letters— From Mr J. A. Smith, enclosing the card of Mr Chad, the appointed Secretary to the British Legation in the United States; and a Letter of Introduction of Mr Chad, from Mr Everett at the Hague— Mr Chad has been attached to the British Legation there, and also at Paris— He left the Letter, and his Card, at the Office— From Mr Beasley, enclosing a Letter to him from a Mr Guestier, his wife’s uncle, at Baltimore. Mr Guestier had fitted out two ships for Europe and thence to the British Possessions in the East-Indies, on the expectation that the indirect trade in American Vessels, with India was stipulated for in the Commercial Convention of 3. July 1815. But on the publication of the Convention, he had doubts, as there was a regulation of the British Government in India, in the year 1811. excluding all American Vessels, unless direct, from the United States— He therefore requests Mr Beasley to apply to Lord Bathurst’s Office, for information, whether the two Vessels will be admitted, and to write to the Supercargoes at Cowes and at Leghorn, according to the answer he may receive. But Mr Beasley, knowing the difficulty of obtaining the information from the British Government, applies for it to me— From Mr Maury at Liverpool acknowledging the receipt of my order in his favour, upon Messrs: Baring Brothers and Co.— And From W and J. Willink of Amsterdam in answer to my last Letter to them.— It was near eleven O’Clock when the Play finished— The most remarkable part of it was the performance of several airs upon the flute, by a boy named Stebbing, only four years old— We got home about half past twelve.— Visits from Mr: & the Miss Vaughan’s.

4. VII:45. Mrs: Adams was the whole day very unwell; and I can give no good account of the time. Breakfast time came, and I had written only a short answer to Mr Beasley, and a few lines of Journal.— I attended Church with all the Children— Mr Millman read Prayers for the fifth Sunday after the Epiphany, and a Sermon from Jeremiah XXIII.24. Can any hide himself in secret places, that I shall not see him?
Saith the Lord. Mr Millman’s delivery and reading grows worse instead of improving, by practice. The Church was very thinly attended. About a hundred boys of Dr Nicholas’s school were there— I returned after Church immediately home; but before I could sit down to writing, I had a visit from General Scott, Coll: Drayton and Mr Carter— The General has been greatly disgusted, at the state of things which he has witnessed in France— He proposes to return shortly to the United States. He strongly expressed his wish that the Government of the U.S. would acknowledge the Independence of the South-Americans, and take part with them against Spain— When these Gentlemen were gone, I went with George, and returned the visit of Mr Fletcher and his Son— They were not at home, and I left Cards— On our return home we found Mr J. A. Smith— He had come from town with Mr and Mrs: Delafield, who came to pay a visit; but Mrs Adams was too unwell to see them. Mr Smith, brought me a Letter from Baring Brothers and Co. mentioning that they had paid my draft in favour of Mr Maury, and had been obliged to take a receipt for the money, on a ten shilling Stamp— John and Charles this Evening returned to School.

5. VII:30. Mrs: Adams was so ill in the Night that I was obliged about one O’Clock this Morning to rise, and rouse up Lucy to come to her. It was between two and three before she got any rest, and my rising hour this morning was proportionably postponed. George after reading only the part of his daily task, which had been left yesterday unfinished, went to School this morning at Eight— I answered the Letter, yesterday received from the Brothers Baring; brought up the arrears of my Journal, and began a despatch to the Secretary of State. Mr J. A. Smith went to town in the Curricle, and sent out by the Coachman two copies of the Treaties which have just been communicated to Parliament— There are between seventy and eighty Treaties and Conventions— Besides Protocols, Declarations, and despatches—and will form two large Folio Volumes— After dinner I read a few pages of Foster’s Essay.

6. V:15. George read his six Chapters of the French Bible before he went to school. I received a Note from Mr Grubb, enclosing four Boston Newspapers, of the last days of December. I was engaged all the Morning in writing; there was an incessant rain, the whole day, notwithstanding which I walked about half an hour before dinner. In the Evening I finished reading Foster’s Essays, with the last of which I have been much less pleased than with those that precede it. There is an appearance of religious fanaticism about it, which has somewhat disgusted me. His doctrine that all elegant Literature antient and modern is at open and implacable War, with the Gospel, is in my opinion an extreme exaggeration.— I loath his invectives against Homer and the other great antient Poets, and believe there is error at the very foundation of his theory. There is indeed exaggeration and the mark of enthusiasm in all the Essays, but of the last the basis itself is rotten— The Style of them all is elegant, and full of Spirit.

7. V:30. On rising, I found the ground entirely covered with Snow, which had fallen in the Night. It was about three inches deep, and more than has fallen before, this winter. Mrs Adams though unwell, went into London— She brought out a Letter from Mr Saml: J. Browne dated at the London Coffee-House; informing me that he has arrived with despatches for me from the Government of the United States and proposing to wait on me, at any hour that may be agreeable to me— At the same time came an Irish Newspaper, the Waterford Mirror, of the 3d: instant, addressed to the same Mr Browne, to my care, and containing an Article, announcing that Mr Browne had on the preceding Wednesday, passed through that City, on his way from Cork, charged with despatches &c— I had likewise a Letter this morning from Coll Aspinwall the Consul at London, mentioning that Extra charges of Pilotage, Light-Money &c are still levied at the Trinity House upon American Vessells, and submitting, whether it is not contrary to the Convention of 3. July last— I walked an hour before dinner, and was engaged most of the day upon the despatch to the Secretary of State, which I nearly finished. Cold Evening. [symbols]

8. V:15. Finished the despatch for the Secretary of State; answered the Letters from Coll: Aspinwall, and from Mr Browne, and appointed three O’Clock this afternoon to see Mr Browne at Craven Street. Wrote a short Letter to my Mother and made up my packets. Went into London, taking George with me. Mrs. Adams was so unwell that she concluded not to go and I took her excuse to Mr and Mrs Dickason. We reached the Office just at three— Mr Browne had already been there, and left the despatches— There was a duplicate of the Letter from the Secretary of State of 10. December. One of 12. Decr: concerning Dr Bollmann, and another relating to the Brig Nanina, with a third of the same date from Mr Purviance, a clerk in the Department— One from Mr Monroe of 16. December enclosing the application from Mr Williams of the Senate, to procure copies of Governor Dobbs’s Commission and Instructions; and one of 25. Decr. being a recommendation of Mr Browne. Also copies of the Correspondence between General Cass, and the British Coll: James, respecting the Indian killed, at Gros Isle &c. and a Bundle of the National Intelligencer. And a Letter from Mr John Jacob Astor at New-York; mentioning that he had forwarded by Captain Rogers of the Ship Sapor, bound to Liverpool, and by Coll: Talmadge; but the latter, are the same brought by Mr Browne. The others must be those received on the 18th: ulto: as having been brought by the Seapoy.— Besides the despatches, there was a Letter from Mr Harris at St. Petersburg, of 5. January, enclosing the Emperor Alexander’s Ukaze, expelling the Jesuits from his dominions; which he says has given universal satisfaction; and informing me that he will be under the necessity of drawing upon me, for the arrears of his Salary— And a Letter from one Thomas Kendall; an Englishman wanting a Passport to go to America— I called at Brunet’s Hotel, to see General Scott, and Mr Carter, neither of whom being at his lodgings I left Cards— Coll: Drayton does not lodge there, and thus I could not return his visit— I walked back, to Craven Street; and on the way stopped at Bish’s Office, and purchased a quarter of a Lottery-ticket for Mrs Adams— Stopped also at Williams’s, the
Stationer’s, where I took some Books and Paper. Mr Addams, of Doctor’s Commons called upon me, about the Accounts of Cresswell and Addams against General Lyman’s Estate— I had a few days since a Letter from them on the same subject— They say that their Correspondent at Washington informs them that upon application at the Secretary of State’s Office, he had been told that I had now received instructions to settle their Account— I assured him that I had received no such Instructions, nor any answer from the State Department, to the Letters which I wrote last Summer respecting their Accounts; and I promised Mr Addams to give him information as soon as I do receive Instructions relating to them— I had scarcely time to read through my despatches, when six O’Clock came. We left George, to dine at a Coffee-House, and then go to the Strand Theatre; and Mr Smith and I went and dined with Mr. and Mrs Dickason. The company, were Mr Guillemard, formerly one of the British Commissioners at Philadelphia, under the Treaty of 1794. and his Lady. a Mr: Mrs and Miss Clay—Mr and Mrs King. two Mr Slade’s, Gentlemen belonging to Doctors Commons; Mr Nevett, and some other Gentlemen whom I did not know— There were two daughters of Mr: Dickason born at Boston, and a Son; a young man. After dinner the young Ladies played on the Piano— At Table the Conversation was partly political, and there was some discussion concerning Sir Robert Wilson, Captain Huchinson, and Mr Bruce, three Englishmen now imprisoned in Paris, for having assisted La Valette in making his escape. The opinions were various, but the majority were in favour of the Englishmen— We returned to Craven Street about half-past ten O’Clock, and I waited there more than an hour for George, before the Play finished— It was half past One O’Clock in the morning when we reached home— The weather very Cold.

9. VII:15. On rising this Morning I found it impossible to write. I put one of my thermometers out at the window, and it fell to eight degrees of Fahrenheit above 0—equal to -11. of Reaumur— The sky was clear and during the day the Snow thawed in the Sun. I began reading the file of National Intelligencers yesterday received, and they absorbed the day until my walking hour before dinner. I went round through Hanwell and Ealing. I received yesterday a second Note from the Countess Dowager of Dunmore, enclosing the Letter for Mr Monroe, which she persists in requesting me to forward, though I have given her fair notice that her daughter Lady Virginia, has nothing to expect from the State, the name of which she bears— And this Evening’s Post brought Letters from Mr Montreal, at St: Petersburg, and from my old acquaintance, Count or Baron Bussche Hünnefeldt, whom I knew as the Westphalian Minister at St Petersburg.— Montreal’s Letter encloses one for Mr W. Gray of Boston; and copies of Letters from Mr Gray to him; with complaints against two of his Captains, who arrived there last Summer, and who avoided consigning their Cargoes to Mr Montreal’s house.— Bussche’s Letter is also complaining— He says that his Westphalian Mission to Russia, has been the occasion of disgracing him in the mind of his Sovereign, the Prince Regent of England; that it has exposed him to many troubles and afflictions; and that he has written to the Hanoverian Minister here Count Munster, asking for his intercession to restore him to favour, and has referred him to my testimony, with regard to his real Sentiments while he was in Russia. He requests me to say of him what I really think— There was likewise a Cover from Mr J. A. Smith enclosing a Card, from the Lord Mayor, and the Lady Mayoress, to Mrs Adams and me, inviting us to meet the Austrian Archdukes, at a dinner at the Mansion House, on Monday the 19th: instt.

10. VI:15. Fahrenheit’s Thermometer this morning at ten. Equal to -10 of Reaumur. And to my great regret I found it again impossible to write steadily before Breakfast— Arrears in the journal are the necessary consequence, and arrears of Correspondence follow of course. George is now afflicted with a violent tooth-ache, and returned from school after having been there about an hour this Morning. Dr Nicholas, is also extremely ill with the Gout in his Stomach, notwithstanding the magnet which he wears hung round his neck as an amulet against it; he has had great confidence in it until now— I answered the Notes of the Lord Mayor, and of Mr and Mrs Delafield, and accepted their invitations— Went into London alone. Called to return the visit of Mr G. W. Chad, but he was not at his lodgings— I left a Card— I thence went to Prince Esterhazy’s, the Austrian Ambassador’s. The Prince was gone to Brighton, but Mr Neumann the Secretary of the Embassy was at home and I saw him— He shewed me the despatch from his Government to the Prince, respecting the ships at Venice, which they propose to sell to the American Government— And the list of the ships— I told him that I had already heard something upon the subject, from Dr: Bollmann, to whom Prince Metternich had made the offer of the sale of three of them, and had named the prices which would be taken for them— That Bollmann was now in America, and in answer to the Communications made through him, I had been instructed to say that they were received with pleasure by the Government of the United States, who would be happy to cultivate the most friendly relations with Austria. That the proposals would be considered with attention, and the views of the American Government concerning them be made known hereafter. I told Neumann that I had only Bollmann’s verbal authority, for what Prince Metternich had said to him
and he had told me the Prince had made it as a confidential proposal, and requested that it might be kept secret— Neumann looked over his despatch again, and told me that it was so— He had not observed it before, but he now perceived that secrecy was enjoined. I desired him to write to his Government, and ask them to fix the prices at which they would dispose of the Ships— He promised to send me a copy of the proposals as they were, in German, and I asked him to send a French or English Translation with the original— I told him that I wished to be presented to the Archdukes John and Lewis, who are now here, particularly as I had received an invitation from the Lord Mayor, to dine on the 19th instant, in company with them, at the Mansion House— I mentioned that I had been acquainted at St. Petersburg with Count St. Julien who accompanies them. He sent to their house which is only a few doors from the Ambassador’s, to enquire if they or Count St Julien were at home; but they were gone out. He said he would inform me by a Note, a day or two before hand, when they would receive me, and whether in full dress or otherwise— I told him that when they first arrived I had heard, I time had been appointed at which the other foreign Ministers were presented to them; but I was then confined to my house by illness, and had besides received no notice of the presentation— Probably because I was not in town— He said a notification had certainly been sent to me, but I have no doubt he was mistaken. He said the dinner at the Mansion house would be a dinner of parade. From him I went to the Bookseller, Booth’s and took a Catalogue and some Books— Thence to the Westminster Library, Jermyn Street; where I left Foster’s Essays, and took the last year’s Monthly Reviews. Then I called at Mr G. W. Apthorp’s lodgings in the Strand, but he was not at home. It was three O’Clock by the time when I reached my Office— I ordered the Coachman to leave the Stables at 5 O’Clock, and overtake me on the Brentford Road— I made up for the Secretary of State, the Packets to be sent by Mr Stephen Price; who is to go next Monday for Liverpool to embark for New-York— I had asked Mr J. A. Smith to invite this Gentleman and his brother to come out and dine with us to-morrow; but they are both engaged. Mr Smith asked me for money on account of his salary. He had no order upon any person here to receive it— And he has no arrangement with the Government, with respect to the time from which it is to commence— He says he does not intend to stay here long, as he can do much better at New-York, by his Profession— I gave him an order upon the Brothers Baring & Co: for 500 Dollars being a Quarter’s Salary. It was half past four when I left the Office, and the Carriage overtook me just beyond the Kensington grate— I was at home at Six; and found George suffering extreme pain with the tooth-ache. Dr Cooke had been sent for, but declined drawing the tooth which he said was so much decayed that it could safely drawn only by a professional dentist— John and Charles were at home and dined with us— They had brought with them, their Schoolmates Baker and Gattey— After dinner they all returned to School together.

11. VII:15. The weather had moderated much, and Fahrenheit’s Thermometer this Morning was at 30—only two degrees below the freezing point. Yet I found myself unable to write, and my arrears of all kinds accumulate. Instead of writing, I read before breakfast, and in a Volume of Debrett’s Peerage, found that the Miss Kinnaird, who married a Mr Dana, and concerning whose Son, Mr Galloway of Hagar’s town has written requesting me to make enquiries, was an Aunt of Lord Kinnaird, and of Mr Douglas Kinnaird— From one of whom I shall therefore endeavour to obtain the desired information— I attended Church, with Mrs Adams— Mr Millman read Prayers for Septuagesima Sunday. Mr Carr read an Old Sermon, from Proverbs XXIV.9. first part of the verse. “The thought of foolishness is Sin.” There is nothing to be said of Mr Carr’s Sermons— After Church I wrote a few lines, not without difficulty. Received from Coll: Aspinwall a reply to the answer I wrote him relative to the extra-charges still levied here at the Trinity House, upon American Vessels— Walk of about an hour before dinner— There was Snow, but towards Evening the weather became clear and Cold again— After dinner I read part of the Monthly Review for January of last year. At my Office yesterday I found a Youth of about fifteen, named John Langdon Elwyn, a Grandson of Mr John Langdon of Portsmouth, from whom he brought me a Letter of Introduction together with one, from his father T. Langdon Elwyn— He came from America, with, and under the care of Coll: Aspinwall— Has been until last week, with his Uncle at Clifton, and is to return to him next week.

12. V:45. Thermometer this Morning at 18, or -6 of Réaumur— I could not write a line before Breakfast— Read Hamilton upon the national debt of Great-Britain— Mrs Adams went into London with George, who had his tooth drawn by a Mr Fox a dentist. I began the draft of a Note to Lord Castlereagh; a reply to Lord Bathurst’s answer concerning the carrying away of the Slaves— This is one of the Subjects which has been laying over, ever since my illness. Wrote a few lines only in this Journal, still three days in arrear— Received by the Morning’s Post, a Letter from Mr H. Jackson our Chargé d’Affaires at Paris, enclosing Copies of two Notes from him to the Duke of Richelieu, the French Minister of Foreign Affairs; and a Letter from Major Mercer to General Scott— Mrs Adams brought out with her a Letter from W. & J. Willink of Amsterdam, enclosing a Certificate of U.S. Stock, and other Papers, and a Letter from Mr W. Gray of Boston, recommendatory of Mr. William Wyer, who left it at the Office with his Card— It is dated in September 1814. At which time Mr Wyer embarked and came to France. Since then he has been hitherto in France, and I have had some Correspondence with him. He is an Agent for Mr Gray— Walk before dinner, through Gunnersbury and Brentford— After dinner I went through the remainder of the Monthly Review of January 1815. The style of this Review has very much fallen off. The most curious Article is Lucien Buonaparte’s Poem of Charlemagne—Lucien was not born a Poet. This is my wife’s Birth-day.

13. V:15. Thermometer again at 18, and again disqualified me for writing before Breakfast. I employed the time, not so usefully as in reading— That is, with trifles. George resumed again his reading, after two more days of interruption; and went to School. I finished all to the concluding paragraph, the draft of the Note to Lord Castlereagh concerning the Slaves carried away. and the rest of the Morning I was engaged in retrieving the arrears of the journal which I effected. George returned home from school at three O’Clock, and walked with me before dinner— Mr Connell came out and made me a visit— He is lately from America. Has been twice to the West-Indies since we saw him at Ghent. He says there was some misunderstanding between Mr Monroe, and Mr Gallatin at Washington last Autumn.— In the Evening I read two or three Articles in the Monthly Review of last February.

14. V: The weather has moderated, and I was able to write again before Breakfast. I therefore prepared a short Note to Lord Castlereagh upon the extra duties and charges upon American Vessels, still levied in this Country— I made the draft, the Note itself, and a Copy of it; and then enclosed the Note, under a cover to Mr J. A. Smith, requesting him to deliver it this day, at the Foreign Office.— I next took up my draft of the Note concerning the Slaves, and made out part of a fair copy of it, which I could not finish. I received two Letters from Coll: Aspinwall— In the Evening, I read again in the Monthly Review of last February. Walk to Hanwell and Ealing.

15. V: Finished the fair Copy of the Note to Lord Castlereagh, relative to the Slaves carried away; but could accomplish nothing more. Received enclosures from Mr J. A. Smith— A Note from Prince Esterhazy, the Austrian Ambassador, with a list of the Ships at Venice, in German, and a French Translation. Also a Note from Mr de Neumann informing me, that the Austrian Archdukes John and Lewis, would receive me, en frac, next Sunday at 12. O’Clock Noon— And a copy of a long memorial to the Lords of the Treasury, by an American named George Cooke, a native of Boston; complaining that his Factory at the Rio Pongus on the Coast of Africa has been destroyed by a British armed force—himself seized, imprisoned, manacled and fettered, condemned after a mock trial, to fourteen years transportation. and after being brought as a malefactor to England, where he suffered several Months Imprisonment, had the rest of his sentence remitted by the Prince Regent, after which he was falsely and calumniously represented by a published Report of the African Institution, as having pleaded guilty at his trial, and as pardoned only upon some point of informality. With this there was a copy of a Note from the Spanish Ambassador, Count Fernan Nuñez to Lord Castlereagh, requiring that Mr Page, an Agent for certain Spanish Subjects, who were involved in the same illegal trial, may be allowed to enter an appeal upon the judgment of that trial, although the year and day allowed generally for such appeals is elapsed.— I took these Papers into London with me, and read them on the way. Pio went in with me. I first called at Mr Douglas Kinnaird’s house—Clarges Street— He was not at home, but his brother, Lord Kinnaird was there. He was waiting for a Gentleman, and I stopped only a few minutes— He told me that he should publish to-morrow, a statement of facts, relative to the order which he received about a fortnight ago, to quit Paris, and the kingdom of France. He said he had nothing to complain of in the conduct of this Government—Liverpool and Castlereagh had both behaved very handsomely to him. But the jealousy and hatred of the French Government towards every thing English was inconceivable. He said there would immediately be published a Volume of Letters written in Paris by Mr Hobhouse which would give a very accurate account of the state of things in France— I then told him that I had called upon his brother to enquire, if he could give me any information respecting a person, by the name of William Pulteney Dana— Perhaps he, himself could— He said yes— He was a kinsman of their family— Son of Clergyman in Shropshire— But what was the object of my enquiry? He hoped he had not been doing any mischief— No certainly—no mischief— But he had been some years since in America; had married there; and left a daughter, now about eleven years old, who had not heard from him for several years, and in behalf of whom I was requested to make these enquiries— He said that he or his brother could in the course of a day or two give me all the information that could be desired. I gave him Mr Galloway’s Letter, observing that I had no personal acquaintance with that Gentleman, some of whose observations I thought might as well have been omitted— But he would excuse them in consideration of the main object, which was to serve the young Lady.— He said that Mr Dana was a very Strange, eccentric and obstinate man. That he had given a great deal of trouble to the family; who had never been able to do any thing with him; and that he was very poor— He promised to return me Mr Galloway’s Letter in a day or two, with a Note of all the information requested— After calling at the circulating Library to change some books for Mrs Adams, I went to a house Agent’s in Bond Street, and enquired the Rent of a House in Grosvenor Square, advertised to be let, furnished, for one or two years. 800 Guineas— It was too much, and I declined taking a ticket to see the house—the man said there was a very good house in Devonshire Street to let for 650 Guineas. I told him I did not wish to exceed 400— Perhaps you may find such a house, said he, in Gloucester Place,
or in Baker Street. I then went and paid a visit to Mr Bourke the Danish Minister— Enquired of him whether his Lady, would go to the Lord Mayor’s dinner next Monday— He said no— And he doubted whether he should go himself— Nothing could be more disagreeable then those parties— It was a mere scramble.— He had been the year before last, at the dinner on Lord Mayor’s day, and was fully determined never to go there again— The foreign Ministers were not treated with common civility— They were seated at a third Table; below the subalterns of the Public-Offices. Mr Bourke shewed me his collection of Miniature Pictures of all the kings to whom he has been accredited, and from whom he received them as presents— He said they had almost all been dethroned. They were the last king of Poland. the present king of Naples the last and present kings of Sweden, and of Spain. and the present, or rather late king of Great-Britain— He spoke particularly of Ferdinand, the present king of Spain, and said that strange as his conduct appeared, he was very much beloved in Spain— He said that some time ago, he, and Fernan-Nuñez had to sign a Treaty— And it was a long time before Fernan Nuñez would sign it in French— He said they had abolished the French language in Spain; and finally agreed to sign it in French, only because Bourke offered him as the alternative to sign it, both in Spanish and Danish, or in Latin— From Mr Bourke’s I went and called at Mr Lawrence’s lodgings. 10. Blenheim Street; but he was out. It was past 3 O’Clock when I got to the Office in Craven Street— I found there Mr Browne, a merchant in the City and a Mr Moore: and mistook the former for the Mr Browne, who lately brought me despatches from America. I was engaged until half past four, reading private papers, and making up a Packet for the Secretary of State, to go by Mr Lawrence, who leaves town for Liverpool and New-York to-morrow Morning. I then called at a Bookseller’s in Charing-Cross and bespoke some books—then walked on, and was overtaken by the Carriage, just beyond the Kensington grate— The Carriage had missed Richard, and we came home without him— When I got home, I found enclosures from Mr J. A. Smith, a long Letter from Mr Page to Viscount Sidmouth. Letters from Mr Grubb and from Messrs: Service and Studley, with a notice of an examination of Scholars at Mr Matheson’s Academy, and offers of tickets. Service and Studley say this is the improved system of Education which they proposed to introduce in America— There was also a Letter from Mr Richard M’Call, the Consul at Barcelona.

16. V:15. I answered the Note, yesterday received from Prince Esterhazy the Austrian Ambassador, and the Letters from Coll: Aspinwall, and Mr Grubb. Sent them into London by the Coachman who went with Lucy, upon an errand for Mrs Adams. The rest of the morning I was bringing up the last three days of my Journal. Walk to Brentford and Ealing an hour before dinner. The Evening’s Post, brought me a cover from Mr J. A. Smith, enclosing the Note to Lord Castlereagh, which I examined, signed, sealed up, and enclosed again to Mr. Smith, to go by the Post-Office to-morrow Morning. There was also a Letter from Mr Henry Jackson, our Chargé d’Affaires at Paris; dated January 13. and brought by his nephew Mr Jabez Jackson. It enclosed a variety of Letters to be delivered, and forwarded; a copy of a Letter from Mr Shaler at Algiers of 16. December last. and two written applications from Sir George Jackson of Beach Hill, in Surry, and of Fork Hill, in the County of Armagh, in Ireland, requesting, for particular family reasons to be attached to the American Embassy, as private Secretary, or in any other capacity; and if I agree to his request, that I would enquire explicitly of his Britannick Majesty’s Ministers, without mentioning any name, whether if I should appoint a British Subject one of my private Secretaries, the Court of Great-Britain would allow him the privileges and protection accorded to all members of Embassies; and that I would inform him, whether if I should return home in the Spring, and leave a Chargé d’Affaires, Sir George could still remain as private Secretary to the Chargé d’Affaires, with the same privileges, & protection— I read over Mr Page’s Letter to Lord Sidmouth; which though very long gave me no clear idea of the Subject to which it relates. Mrs Adams was very unwell the whole day, with rhumatic symptoms, and fainted soon after dinner.

17. V:30. The Sun rises this day at 7. A.M. and sets at 5. P.M. I still rise by candle-light, but the day comes soon afterwards— My only atchievement this day was a despatch to the Secretary of State. We had company to dinner. Coll: and Mrs. Aspinwall, Mr: and Mrs C. King—Mr and Mrs Von Harten and Miss Carnell, Major General Scott, Coll: Drayton, and Mr J. A. Smith. Mr Carter sent an excuse being very unwell. Mr Von Harten who had been in the City, came just after we had sat down to table. There was much Conversation, and particularly between General Scott and Mr King. General Scott has much of the ardour of youth combining with a large share of military ambition— He has shortened his European tour, and although he had leave of absence for two years, and left the United States last July he proposes now to return home immediately; and goes to Liverpool, to embark about the middle of the next Month. He told me that he wished to return in time to have the command at New-York, which is now vacant— We sat late at table, and it was about one in the morning when the Company left us— I received a letter from Lieutt: F. Kinloch at Charleston S.C. enclosing one for Mr John West; and a Letter from a Mr Henry Evans, who is anxious to establish in the U.S. manufactures of Gunpowder— John met with an accident this day; but was not materially hurt. Mr Smith passed the Night here.

18. VII:30. I was obliged to go to London this morning, and Mr J. A. Smith went in with me. He left me at Hyde Park corner, and I went first to the Austrian Ambassador, Prince Esterhazy’s in Stratford Place— The Archdukes were then at Mass at his house, but it finished soon after— I saw the Prince for a few minutes, and he went with me to the house where the Archdukes reside— I there found
Count St: Julien our old acquaintance, and Baron Jacobi the Prussian Minister was in the drawing Room. The Dutch Ambassador, Baron Fagel came in shortly afterwards— The Austrian Consul, and another Gentleman were likewise there— We were all introduced to the Archdukes John and Louis, brothers of the present Emperor of Austria. They were in plain, undress, frock Coats, as were all the visitors, excepting Baron Fagel, who was full dressed. The Archdukes are young men, apparently between 25 and 30: they have been travelling in England and Scotland, since the month of October, and are to leave this Country about the end of the Month— Count St: Julien, told me where all the Secretaries of his old Legation, at St: Petersburg now are— Lebzeltern at Rome, Marechal in the army—Berks, at Copenhagen, and Sturmer in France; where he is just married, and is coming to England to embark for St Helena, to be the Austrian Commissioner, or as St: Julien said, laughing, to be one of Bonaparte’s jailers, and fellow-prisoners.— I spoke to St Julien, about our old Colleague Bussche, and asked him, if he should have an opportunity, to say a good word for him to Count Munster, the Hanoverian Minister— I told him what Bussche had written to me, and the difficulties in which he is now involved.— He promised to speak to Count Munster, and to give testimony in his favour. From the Archdukes, I went, and called at Mr Alexander Baring’s house in Portman Square, but he was not at home and I left a Card— Thence to the Portuguese Ministers, where I left the two Letters for Rio Janeiro received the other day from Mr Jackson at Paris— I then called at Fenton’s Hotel, St: James’s Street, and saw Lord Kinnaird, with whom I found Mr Benjamin Constant. He went away immediately afterwards— Lord Kinnaird gave me one of his pamphlets which he is publishing; concerning his having been ordered to quit France— It is a Letter to the Earl of Liverpool—while I was with him, his publisher Ridgway came in, he corrected some typographical errors, and said he had promised to review Mr Hobhouse’s Letters from Paris— He told me that Mr W. P. Dana, had sent to America, for his daughter, and asked me whether, that would be a sufficient answer to the enquiries in the Letter— I said nothing further could be necessary, and asked him to return me the Letter— He said his brother had it; and he would speak to him to have it returned as soon as possible— I went to Craven Street, and found Mr Grubb at the Office— Gave him a Letter which had been enclosed to me, for Mr Franklin, whom he said he should see this day. I left other Letters at the Office, to be forwarded by the Post, and as it snowed, the Carriage returned for me at five— It was almost seven when I got home— Mr Von Harten had sent me the Abbé de Pradt, Archbishop of Malines’s book upon the Congress of Vienna— Our Sons John and Charles returned after dinner to School.

19. VI:30. Made up a Packet of the Treaties lately communicated to Parliament, to send to the Secretary of State. Went into London, soon after Breakfast. Called at Lord Holland’s. N. 20—Saville-Row, and left a Card, with a Letter for him, from General La Fayette, received last week, from Mr Jackson— Then went to the Office in Craven Street, where I found Mr Connell.— He had brought me the continuation of Niles’s Register, of which he sent me last Winter, the first six volumes. There were also despatches from the Department of State. For myself, nothing but duplicates and a letter from Mr Purviance of 11. January. But it enclosed a large despatch for Mr Harris at St. Petersburg, and having been sent from Liverpool by the Post, came charged, with nearly £3. Sterling for Postage— There was a short Letter from Mr John Jacob Astor of New-York, by whom the despatches were forwarded— Mr J. A. Smith had a Letter from Mr: Ogden Edwards of New-York, 13. Jany: enclosing one from Mr Nathan Sanford, Senator of the State of New-York in Congress. of Jany: 9. with the information that he, J. A. Smith, had been nominated as Secretary of Legation to Great-Britain, and confirmed by vote of the Senate, the day before. Mr. Connell sat with us about half an hour, and was scarcely gone, when Mr Page came in. He is the agent of a Mr George Cook, an American Citizen, who has a memorial pending before the Lords of the Treasury, which has been referred to Lord Sidmouth to report upon it— Mr. Page wants an immediate answer to the memorial, and wishes me to address Lord Castlereagh concerning it— He kept me, until near six O’Clock, talking upon the subject, and then went to send me more documents concerning it. I had barely time to dress, and go to the Mansion-House, to the Party, given by the Lord Mayor and the Lady Mayoress, to the Archdukes John and Lewis of Austria— All the Princes of the Blood-Royal, the Ministers of the Country, and the Foreign Ambassadors had been invited; but there were present, only the Duke of Kent— None of the Ministers of State— The Austrian Ambassador— The Ministers of Bavaria, Portugal, Wurtemberg and myself. The rest of the company, consisted of Lord and Lady Torrington, and the Aldermen and other City Officers; their wives and daughters. About sixty sat down to table. Mr Braham was there to sing; and Mr Perry, Editor of the Morning Chronicle, I suppose to publish an account of the Entertainment— The dinner was good— The wines generally indifferent. Several singular City usages were observed— The preliminary to the drinking of the Toasts was by two large gold or gilt cups being brought, and the Lord Mayor and Lady Mayoress drank from them to the health of all their company, a clerk or Steward behind the Lord mayor, addressing by name all the principal guests, and announcing
that the Lord Mayor and the Lady Mayoress drank to them all, in “loving Cups.”— The same Cups were then passed round, to all the company, and every guest in turn drank from them— Two Basons and Ewers were afterwards brought, and passed round in the same way to all the company— Rose-water was poured into the Bason from year; and every guest in turn, after the Lord Mayor and Lady Mayoress, dipped a corner of his napkin into the bason, and wiped his lips— Then came the toasts, the paper of which was given to the Duke of Kent, who arranged their order— The King—the Prince Regent—The Queen and Royal Family—The Emperor of Austria. The Archdukes John and Lewis, successively—The Duke of Kent—The Emperor of Russia and king of Prussia whose Ministers were not present. (This toast was given by Prince Esterhazy, the Austrian Ambassador.) The king of Bavaria—the King of Wurtemberg; the Prince Regent of Portugal, and the United States of America— At these toasts, all except the first, there were cheers of three times three.— After the first Braham sung God save the King.— And after the Queen and Royal family, another Song— For this time Rule Britannia was omitted. At the four or five first toasts, the Steward behind the Lord Mayor, repeated the call of names of the guests, and announced the toast— The Ladies then retired; after which the Lord Mayor announced some of the toasts and the Duke of Kent the others. When the Archduke John was given, he gave in return the Lord Mayor, and the City of London; the Archduke Louis, (by Prince Esterhazy) the Duke of York and the British Army— The Duke of Kent gave the Lady Mayoress— The Bavarian Minister, in return for his king’s health, the British Nation, which assists all Nations. The Wurtemberg Minister, permanency to the general Peace—the Portuguese Minister, the Duke of Wellington and the British Army in Portugal— The Duke of Kent gave the United States of America, and perpetuity to the Friendship between Great-Britain and them. on which addressing the Lord Mayor, I said that sensibly affected as I was by the honour done by his Royal Highness to my Country by the toast he had given, it was impossible for me to do more than to echo the sentiment he had expressed— I would ask leave therefore to offer in a two fold manner, the earnest wish I entertained—that between the antient and the new hemisphere there may henceforth be no division other than that of the ocean; and that the harmony between Great-Britain and the United States may be as lasting as the language and the principles common to both. This was very well received, and the company immediately afterwards rose in good humour from table. The company passed then into the Egyptian Hall, where there was a Ball; of four or five hundred persons— I met a Mr Sharp, whom I had seen last Summer at Earl Grey’s, and who now told me that he had just obtained a Seat in Parliament. I had some conversation with him, and with Mr Perry; It was about two in the Morning when I left the Mansion House— There was an important debate in both Houses of Parliament, this Evening; upon the Treaties—which was the cause why all the Ministers of State, and almost all the members of both houses were absent— I stopped at Craven Street, to take the things I had left there; and it was half past three in the morning when I reached home— Mrs Adams was up, waiting for me— She had sent an excuse for herself.

20. IX. I found myself utterly unhinged for writing of any kind, and abandoned the day to reading Niles’s Register— Went cursorily over the numbers brought by Mr Connell; they come down to the beginning of December, and contain some documents which I should have seen before— George comes home from school at 3 O’Clock afternoon on Tuesday’s, and at Noon on Thursday’s and Saturday’s. He walked with me this day before dinner— This Evening’s Post, brought several Letters— One from Mr Page, with his Power of Attorney from George Cook— From Mr Maury at Liverpool mentioning that the despatches for me from the Secretary of State, which I received yesterday, and upon which there was such a heavy charge of Postage, had been inadvertently put into the Post-Office; but the Post Master had refused to return them. One from J. B. Murray and Son of New-York, concerning the case of the Nanina, with a duplicate of the Instructions from the Secretary of State, directing my interposition in that case. And a Packet from Mr Grubb, enclosing Letters from my father and mother, to myself, and my three Sons—dated in December, and to 12. January— They communicate information of the decease of Dr Tufts; an Event which has much afflicted them— He was, excepting my Uncle Peter Boylston Adams, the only remaining friend and relation of the family of that Generation. They both write, and especially my Mother in a depression of Spirits which distresses and alarms me. My Mother at the latest date had been herself very dangerously ill, and was yet confined to her chamber.— May it Please God to spare their lives, and to grant me the mercy of beholding them once more in this world!

21. VII:30. The weather is so mild that the Snow-drops and Crocuses in our Garden are already in blossom. This day they first appeared. I have not yet settled down to any regular occupation, and ranged again all this morning over the numbers of Niles’s Register— The Newspapers from London, yesterday and this day came in only at two or three O’Clock, afternoon; as they contain the debates of the two preceding Nights in the house of Commons, and of Monday at the House of Peers, on the Treaties.— I wrote in this Journal which still falls in arrear; and a note to Count Beroldingen the Minister of Wurtemberg, enclosing the papers received from the Department of State in answer to enquiries
which the Count, by order of his Government had made relating to the Estate of a man named Guber, or Huber, a native of Wurtemberg who died in America— My walk before dinner was to Gunnersbury and Brentford. The morning’s Post, brought me a large mass of Documents from Mr Page, which I had not time or Patience to read, and that of the Evening Letters from Mrs Stockdale, with a printed advertisement, and one from Mr Douglas Kinnaird, informing me that he has sent Mr Galloway’s Letter, to his Cousin Mr Dana, and will return it to me, as soon as he sends it back. [symbols]

22. V:30. Though I rose again this morning about my regular hour, the day for business was short— I wrote to the Secretary of State, and made up the weekly Packet of Newspapers to send him, I also wrote a Note to Lord Castlereagh, upon the subject of George’s Cook’s affair, and took it with me to town. Mrs Adams and myself went and dined with Mr and Mrs: Delafield. We left home between 4 and 5. O’Clock, and were at Craven Street just at 6. Mr Smith was to come to Mr Delafield’s in the Evening; I left with him the Note for Lord Castlereagh to make out the fair copy, which he brought to me, and which I signed, to be delivered at the Foreign Office to-morrow. I found at the Office, a Notice of a Court-Mourning, for a week, to commence this day, for a Princess Caroline Louisa, daughter of the Grand Duke of Saxe-Weimar, and Consort of the Hereditary Grand Duke of Mecklenburg Schwerin. Cousin German to the Queen— A Note from Mr Cooke, Under Secretary of State in the Foreign Department, with a Copy of the Commission and Instructions of Arthur Dobbs as Governor of North-Carolina. A Letter from Mr Thomas Hopkins Gallaudet, an American who is travelling to visit the various Institutions in Europe for the Instruction of the deaf and dumb— With it there were, Letters of Recommendation of him from Judge Brockholst Livingston, Doctor Saml: L. Mitchill of New-York, and Mr Chauncey Goodrich late Lieutenant Governor of Connecticut, but now deceased. Mr Gallaudet is going to Paris, and asks me for Letters to our Minister there, and to the Abbé Sícard.— A Letter from Coll: Aspinwall the Consul, requiring further orders upon the Brothers Baring and Co. for money to defray the expence of relieving and sending home destitute American Seamen— And Notes from Captain Stuart, Mr W. Irving, and Mr C. W. Hare. All these Papers detained me nearly half an hour, and made us late, almost seven, when we got to Mr Delafield’s— The company were, Mr. and Mrs. Dickason, Mr and Mrs C. King, Mr Delafield an Uncle of the Gentleman of the House, Miss Delafield, also a Relation, Coll: Talmadge an American and two other Gentlemen— It was a family Birth-day, and at the same time a sort of celebration of that of General Washington. In the Evening there was a great addition of Company—Coll: Aspinwall, Captain Stuart, Mr J. A. Smith, several other Americans, and several Ladies. Most of them were going to the Masquerade this Night at the Opera— We came away soon after eleven O’Clock, and reached home, about one in the Morning.— Mr Samuel Williams, who was also of the company at dinner, told me that Messrs: W. and J. Willink of Amsterdam had drawn upon him for my account.

23. VII:30. Finding myself, as usual after late hours, and festivity over-night, not well disposed for writing early this Morning, I read over the Commission and Instructions to Governor Dobbs, which have been furnished from the foreign Office. They are documents on many accounts so curious, that I wish I could have a copy of them made, before I send them to America— But they are in one hundred and fourteen folio-pages, which makes it perhaps impossible— I wrote an Answer to Coll: Aspinwall’s Letter, and sent him an order upon the Baring’s for £778 Sterling— Wrote also about a page in this Journal— The weather was like Spring, and I walked to Ealing, Acton, Gunnersbury, Brentford, more than six Miles— By the Evening’s Post, I received a Letter from Messrs: Willink of Amsterdam, enclosing duplicates of the Papers I had received from them on the 12th: instt— My eyes were too weak for reading in the Evening— My English footman Richard Brant gave me notice this day, that his friends were about to do something for him, so that he should be no longer in service; but he said he would stay with me until I could suit myself with another man— He has been a good Servant and will be a loss to us.

24. VI:15. Immediately after Breakfast, I went into London, and went with Mr Smith to Freemason’s Hall, and attended the publick exhibition of a Mr Matheson’s Academy, of boys and girls— This is the improved system of Education, which was among the Projects that Messrs: Service and Studley were desirous of introducing in America. We found Studley there. The meeting was not very fully attended; nor by persons apparently of much note. There were a number of boys and girls from ten to fifteen years of age, stationed in little boxes on both sides of and maintaining a sort of forensic dispute upon the question, of preference between Public and Private Education. They all spoke exactly alike; with the same tone, and the same gestures— The debate was all obviously written by one hand—in a mean, but pedantic Style— The common-place arguments on this hacknied topic were adduced, leaving the scale of course to preponderate in favour of the Public side. The manner of the Speaking was in many respects very good—there was no monotony in the delivery of any one Speaker, but they were speaking machines all cast in one mould— Their pronunciation was all in the lowest vulgarity of the Cockney Style, turning every v
into a w, dropping the aspirate where it should be used, and using it where it should be dropped, and crowding together the syllables so as to suppress the utterance of more than half the vowels— After taxing my patience for about an hour, I left the Hall, with the disputants still in the midst of the discussion, and one of the girls, holding forth upon the Advantages of Public lower Private-Education. There were specimens of Penmanship hung round the room, which gave me no better opinion of Mr Matheson’s Calligraphy, than his Orator gave me of his Rhetoric— I called at the Stationer Williams’s, and took some Articles— Then at the Booksellers Whitmore and Fenn, in Charing-Cross; where I took the Annual Register’s for 1812. 13. and 14. to send to the Secretary of State, the last Edinburgh Review for Mr Jackson at Paris, and Chalmers’s Political Annals of the Colonies to send to Mr. Plumer.— I also called at Bish’s Lottery-Office to enquire for the luck of Mrs A’s ticket, but the Books were at Guildhall, and nothing could be known till Monday Morning.— I was surprized at Craven-Street, by a visit from Major Swett, Son in Law to Mr W. Gray of Boston— He had an open Letter from my father to Mr Gray; a sort of introductory circular to any of his friends in France— Mr Swett came last Summer to France; has been only a few days in this Country, and intends to return to America, in the Galen— He offered to take any things for me— There was a Note from Mr Sharp, with the ninth and tenth Volumes, of a late Edition of Burke’s works in 8vo.— I had ordered the Carriage at five; but walked on before, and was overtaken by it, just at the Kensington Turnpike— When I got home I found my three Sons, and their Schoolmates Sheaffe, Hammond, and F. Williams, who were playing Symphonies upon the flute. They dined with us, and after dinner returned with John and Charles to School. I brought the Edinburgh Review out from town, and read this Evening the Article upon Tweddell’s Remains; with the charges against the Earl of Elgin.

25. V:30. I received yesterday a Letter from Coll: Aspinwall the Consul, asking for a further order upon the Baring’s for £500. This morning I answered it, and enclosed the order— And with it a Letter from Benjamin Griffin, an American in distress, and at a hospital at Bristol, heretofore a prisoner of War, taken in the Argus— I also received yesterday a Letter of the 20th. from Messrs: W. and J. Willink at Amsterdam; which, with the three others lately received from them, this Morning was answered— Attended Church with Mrs Adams and George. Mr Wallington a Clergyman of the neighbourhood read Prayers for, Quinquagesima, or the Sunday before lent— He gave notice that the Church Service would be performed on Wednesday next, being Ash Wednesday or the first day of lent, and also next Friday. He preached from Genesis IX:9. “And I, behold, I establish my covenant with you, and with your children (seed) after you.”— A text taken from the lesson of the day; but the Sermon was an exhortation to Repentance and Temperance, as peculiarly suitable to the approaching Season of Lent, an eulogy upon the lessons selected by the Church for this and the two preceding Sundays; and a defence of the commination, or collection of curses, which are read in the Church Service of Ash-Wednesday after Church we paid visits to the Miss Nicholas’s. and to Mrs Elmsley— Dr Nicholas is yet confined with the gout, and has been very dangerously ill. He is however much better— Mrs Elmsley, is a Sister of Sir Benjamin Hallowell, and Mr Boylston: I had not seen her since the year 1796. before she was married. Her husband was Chief-Justice of Upper-Canada; but she has been these ten years a Widow.— The remainder of the day I kept house, for the rain, and partly wrote the first draft of a Note to Lord Castlereagh, to send with the copies of the Affidavits relating to the Sales by British Officers of the American Slaves they had stolen— In the Evening I read the Article in the Edinburgh Review, upon the project for a Registry of Slaves in the West-Indies, and that upon Sir N. Wraxall

26. V:15. I wrote a Letter to Mr Jackson, our Chargé d’Affaires at Paris, recommending Mr Gallaudet to him, and in answer to several Letters that I have received from him. The rest of the morning was absorbed by this Journal, and by the Newspapers, which containing now the debates in Parliament consume more than their due portion of time— Walked before dinner to Hanwell and Ealing. By the Evening’s Post, I received from Mr Smith the Examiner of Yesterday—A Letter from Mr Luke, the Consul at Belfast, enclosing one from several Masters of American Vessels at Londonderry to Mr Thomas Davenport the Vice-Consul there, complaining of the discrimination between British and American vessels with regard to Passengers. And a Note from the Lord Mayor, reminding me of a dinner party for to-morrow, which he says he mentioned to me, in the presence of Mr Sharp; but he had certainly not mentioned it to me, as inviting me to it; and I know not whether it is to be at the Mansion House, or elsewhere— I read this Evening several Articles in the Edinburgh Review.

div.p:
27. VI: I went into London this Morning, with various objects of attention, and went through one of those hurly-burly days which leave scarcely any distinct recollections behind. On arriving at the Office in Craven Street, I found there Mr Ingraham who had just received, and brought with him his Commission as Consul at Plymouth. There was with him a Mr Hazard of Liverpool whom he introduced to me; and Mr: Jabez Jackson, nephew of our Chargé d’Affaires at Paris, was likewise there.— They remained about half an hour, and were scarcely gone when Mr Connell came in— Soon afterwards, and while he was there a woman; a native of England, but widow of an American Citizen, came for a Passport to go to France with four children under age; which was given to her— Mr Tarbell brought me a Letter of Introduction from my brother— He is just arrived in London with Mrs Tarbell who is a relation of mine, a Granddaughter of the late Doctor Tufts. As soon as they were gone, I went into the City and stopped at Mr Swett’s lodgings, N. 15. Bucklersbury. He came down to the Carriage— I left with him two Packages for my father—one containing Tucker’s Light of Nature, and the other a piece of Cloth for my brother. And also a Letter
to Mr W. Plumer of Epping, New-Hampshire, with Chalmers’s political Annals of the Colonies, which at his request I have procured for him. Mr Swett promised that he would come out and dine with us on Thursday— I then sent Richard to the Mansion House, and ascertained that the dinner mentioned in the Lord Mayor’s Note, was to be there. I proceeded to the Counting House of the Brothers Baring, and sent away the Carriage with orders to come for me at Craven Street, again at half past five. At Mr Baring’s I saw for a moment Mr Labouchere, who told me that he now resided in the Country; and Mr Oliver of Baltimore, who has just returned from his tour to Ireland— He gave me a slip from an American Newspaper, containing an abstract of the Bill for a National Bank which has been brought in to the House of Representatives of the United States— I enquired of Mr: Alexander Baring, whether they had any advices from the Treasury Department since I had seen him— He said they had none— He spoke of the Bill for establishing a Bank, and doubted whether it would succeed. There was such great care taken of the Public interest, in the Bill, that there was nothing left, as inducement to Subscribers— There was too much controul over the Bank given to the Government, and there was a special provision made for the manner in which Specie payments might be suspended which had not a good appearance. I mentioned to Mr Baring the Orders which I had lately given to the Consuls, upon their House, to defray the expence at London and Liverpool of relieving and sending home destitute American Seamen; and told him of the drafts which I expected to receive from Mr Harris at St: Petersburg, and for which I should in that case be obliged to give further orders upon them. He said their accounts with the Treasury to the close of the year were not quite made up; as soon as they should be, they would send them to me. We had some Conversation upon the topics now in discussion in Parliament of which he is a member— I took instead of a draft £500 in Bank Bills, and signed triplicate receipts for it, chargeable upon the diplomatic fund— From Mr Baring’s I walked back to Craven Street where I found Mr George Joy. I had on coming into town in the Morning stopped at Bish’s Lottery-Office, and ascertained that Mrs A’s ticket had drawn a Blank— Mr Joy kept me in Conversation, until near six. He shewed me a Letter from Mr Eustis of the 23d. mentioning that Mr Bourne the Consul at Amsterdam was so ill, that he would probably not live many days longer, and offering in that case the Consulate provisionally to Joy. I asked him if he meant to accept it— He said probably he should; but he has not got over his hankerings for secret Missions—to France, to Spain—to any where— He was going down into the City, and I took him with me, as far, as opposite to the Mansion House when he left me— But I see he means to try another siege, for he enquired when I should be in town again— I told him Friday or Saturday. I wished to have called at the Foreign Office to see Mr Cocke, but found it impossible. At the Mansion House I found a large company assembled; Ladies and Gentlemen— It was a dinner to the Company of Fishmonger’s, of which the Lord Mayor is himself a member. As soon as I went in I was accosted by the Duke of Sussex, who recollected the old acquaintance we had at Berlin— The Lord Mayor introduced me to the Duke of Kent, the Marquis of Lansdowne, Lord Holland, and Lord Erskine, Sir Edward Hamilton, a naval Officer, the Prime Warden of the Company, and other Gentlemen. Mr Sharp was likewise there. The Company consisted of about fifty persons, nearly half of whom were Ladies— I was the only foreign Minister, and I believe the only foreigner present— Lord Holland apologized for not having returned my visit, but I told him I resided out of town— He recollected having seen me in 1800 at Dresden, which he said he supposed I had forgotten, though I certainly had not— The Prime Warden told me that the Company of Fishmongers would themselves give a dinner before long at their Hall, to which they should invite me— The dinner this day, was much like that to the Archdukes; though not quite so formal— The loving Cups, and the Rosewater passed round in the same manner after dinner, and the toasts were announced in the same manner.— The American Minister was given next after the Duke’s of Kent and Sussex; and my own toast at the former dinner was repeated verbatim, by the Duke of Kent— In thanking the Lord Mayor for the honour done me by the toast, as well as by his friendly invitation to this social meeting, I reminded him of the observation made by a distinguished and ingenious traveller in the United States; a foreigner. He had remarked that from the moment when an Englishman landed in the United States, he still found himself at home; while a foreigner of every other Nation, whatever length of time he resided in America, still felt himself a stranger— It was my earnest wish that the first part of this observation might ever prove to be true, and I would add the hope that it might also prove reciprocal— I would say therefore, may every Briton who sets his foot in America, and every American who visits England, still find himself at home— This was very well received; though not so remarkably well, as my former toast; perhaps because according to the regular etiquette of these symposiacs my toast this time ought to have been, the Lord Mayor, and the City of London— The Duke of Kent when toasted gave the Lady Mayoress— The Duke of Sussex, Miss Wood. The Marquis of Lansdowne, Lord Holland, and Lord Erskine, Sir Edward Hamilton, the Prime Warden, and the Company of Fishmongers, were all toasted, and the Lords and Gentlemen, all returned thanks with short Speeches. Mr Sharp told me that he had not yet taken his seat in Parliament, because the Writ was not returned. He also told me that my father had sent him a copy of my Lectures. The Duke of
Sussex was in fine Spirits, and recollected many circumstances which had occurred while we were at Berlin. He frequently mingled the Political topics of the day in his Conversation, and pronounced his decided opposition to the continuance of the property tax and to the proposed large military Establishment. He offered himself to present any petition against the property tax to the house of Peers, and almost canvassed to be made a member of the Fishmongers Company— All the noblemen present are members (honorary) of the company; and so are the Duke of Gloucester, and Earl St: Vincents. both of whom had been invited to the dinner, but sent excuses, the Duke having lost a near Relation, and Lord St Vincent had met with some accident— The Duke of Kent was more reserved than his brother and talked no Politics at all. He told however some humorous anecdotes about the Duke of Sussex, and said that he had been intended first for the Navy, and afterwards for the Church. He was to have been Bishop of Durham; but they set him to write a Sermon, to see what his disposition for the Church was, and instead of a Sermon, he produced a composition of a very different kind— The duke of Kent appealed to him to say himself if it was not so— He answered that he had certainly no vocation for the Church. He said to me that he prided himself especially upon the stability of his Sentiments, and asked me, if I did not find him precisely the same man, that I had known him at Berlin sixteen years ago. I assured him that I was very confident his name would never appear in the Dictionnaire des Girouettes— The Duke holds forth, a little too much of his opposition; and he appears too much occupied with himself. He said he heard they had been caricaturing him— He had not seen the Caricature, but he was told they had represented him standing on the tomb of Charles the first, singing Psalms— The last part he had no particular predilection for; but he broadly hinted that he did not disapprove the execution of Charles the first.— One of his toasts was, may our family never forget the principles which placed us in the Situation which we hold in this Country; which of course was received with great applause— Lord Holland was toasted, as the nephew of Charles Fox, and Lord Erskine, with Trial by Jury— Lord Holland is yet a popular champion, but Erskine has become a pliable Courtier; he answered feebly the toast to him, and his answer was received with faint applause. Lord Holland said that as the nephew of Mr Fox, there was no merit in him for adhering to his principles—but it would make him doubly contemptible if he should abandon them—which was received with high approbation— As soon as the Duke of Sussex withdrew, I left the Mansion House; and after calling at Craven Street, reached home about half past one in the Morning.

28. VIII:30. I wrote a Letter to my father to send by Mr Swett, with the packages of which he has taken charge; and a Letter of recommendation for Mr Gallaudet, to Mr Jackson, our Charge d’Affaires at Paris— Mr Von Harten paid me a Morning visit. He has a plantation in the Island of Cuba, and is alarmed at the Accounts from America, which speak of a rupture between the United States and Spain, as highly probable— Mr Von Harten says that the Country here is all in an uproar, and thinks it in a very desperate Condition; there are strong symptoms of aversion in many parts of the Country to the continuance of the property tax even under the modification of reducing it from ten to five per Cent, which is proposed by the Ministry. Mr Baring told me that they would have a hard run to carry it through the house of Commons, but although the Petitions against it have at length become numerous, and from important bodies, there is a coldness and languor in the proceedings of the opposition to it, which indicate something hollow. The Ministers are pushed very hard upon it just at this time; but they appear inflexible in the determination to carry it. There is likewise much clamour about the supposed distress of the Country, and most especially of the farmers; but the complaints deal much in generalities— And there are strong facts indicating on the contrary a great general national prosperity.— My walk, this day was to Acton and Ealing.— I was too weary for reading after dinner, and retired before nine.

29. V:15. Wrote a Letter to Mr William Gray of Boston, to send by his Son in Law, Major Swett. The remaining leisure of the day I gave to the Journal; which has again fallen two or three days in arrear; and which I could not completely retrieve— George walked with me to the ninth Mile-Stone, upon the Hounslow, or Windsor road. The weather was quite cold. Fahrenheit’s thermometer which I put out of my window this Morning fell to 26. degrees. We had company of American Gentlemen to dinner. Messrs: S. A. Browne, Connell, Hare, Irving, Renwick, J. A. Smith, Speyer, Stuart, Swett, and Wyer. Three of them, Browne, Renwick, and Wyer, I had never seen— The company broke up, about eleven O’Clock. I gave Mr Swett the Letters for my father and for Mr William Gray.

Day. In general the distribution of my time has been like that of the last Month; but I have been oftener in London, and more in company, both at home and abroad— Company leads to late hours at Night, which of course produce late Morning hours which affect all the business of the day— My rising hour has accordingly been this Month extremely irregular, and I have done much less business— Not more than half the writing— The inconvenience of this is not only an accumulation of arrears, but a hurry in the business that I do. My Eyes have recovered, as much as I can expect they ever will, but my hand forsakes me more and more. I pray that I may not be disqualified from writing, almost entirely.
